docs.lead_paragraph: Most Democratic candidates cannot do enough to distance themselves from President Clinton. But not Jim McGovern. Last month the freshman Congressman from Massachusetts made national headlines -- and took what pundits and his Republican opponent called a big political risk -- when he welcomed President Clinton to his hometown just days after Mr. Clinton's grudging and ill-received admission of his involvement with Monica S. Lewinsky. And out on the campaign trail here today, Mr. McGovern was making no secret of where he had been on Friday night. ''I was at the White House last night with the President and First Lady,'' he told the small group of voters gathered in a living room in Paxton, a suburb of this working- class, Democratic stronghold. Mr. McGovern said he had been attending an event honoring the President's efforts in bringing peace to Northern Ireland.

headline.main: An Incumbent Who Is Not Distancing Himself From the President

docs.abstract: Even though most Democratic candidates are frantically distancing themselves from Pres Clinton because of Monica Lewinsky affair, Massachussetts US Repr Jim McGovern has remained loyal; says even though he is disappointed with President's behavior, Lewinsky affair is not what he nor constituents in Third Congressional District want to discuss most; photo; chart; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Attacks on House Speaker Newt Gingrich have been used to tar Republicans so often as to be almost passe, but their power will be tested in a new way on Tuesday by a Congressional candidate who is using them against his fellow Democrats. There is Mr. Gingrich nodding in slow motion on the television screen as the candidate promises, ''Together, we can stop him.'' There is Mr. Gingrich scowling in the mailbox, where photographic negatives and positives alternate for a house-of-mirrors effect over the headline, ''Who'll Stop Him?''

headline.main: Democrat Tries to Use Gingrich as Foil

docs.abstract: Article discusses political advertising campaign being waged by Connecticut Secretary of State Miles S Rapoport, Congressional candidate who is using attacks on House Speaker Newt Gingrich against his fellow Democrats in upcoming primary; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: States have enacted a wide range of new laws to define patients' rights and regulate health maintenance organizations this year, even though similar legislation has become bogged down in Congress. Such proposals have generated bitter conflict in Washington but have attracted broad bipartisan support in many state capitals. Indeed, Republican state legislators have supported many regulatory initiatives opposed by Republicans in Congress. At the state level, ''patient protection'' is often seen as a form of constituent service rather than as an occasion for ideological warfare.

headline.main: States Take Lead in Health Legislation

docs.abstract: States have enacted wide range of new laws to define patients' rights and regulate health maintenance organizations in 1998, even though similar legislation has become bogged down in Congress; proposals have generated bitter conflict in Washington, but has attracted broad bipartisan support in many state capitals, where patient protection is seen as form of constituent service rather than as occasion for ideological warfare; comprehensive patient-protection laws were adopted in 10 states in 1998; were adopted in 17 states in 1997; Republican state legislators have supported many regulatory initiatives opposed by Republicans in Congress (M)
docs.snippet: States have enacted a wide range of new laws to define patients' rights and regulate health maintenance organizations this year, even though similar legislation has become bogged down in Congress.    Such proposals have generated bitter conflict in...

docs.lead_paragraph: For Bill Clinton, as for all Presidents, the White House has been a stage, the symbol of national power and executive authority, its stately rooms reflecting America's noblest aspirations. In the Oval Office, he has met foreign leaders like Boris Yeltsin and Yitzhak Rabin and pondered domestic issues like health care and welfare. He has also used the elegant setting for less lofty purposes, as a political platform and as a place to charm the rich and powerful for campaign contributions or votes.

headline.main: 10 Days in the White House: Public Acts, Private Moments

docs.abstract: Chronology of 10 sexual encounters between former White House intern Monica S Lewinsky and Pres Clinton, between November 1995 and March 1997, as contained in report to Congress by independent counsel, Kenneth W Starr; Clinton wove encounters with Lewinsky into sessions for bill signings, state dinners and meetings with Government officials and foreign dignitaries; their meetings apparently amounted to less than 10 hours over 16 months--even though Lewinsky's life was apparently dominated by her obsession with President; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A 72-year-old man suffered a fatal heart attack today as he and hundreds of other older residents angrily confronted insurance companies over plans to stop their supplemental Medicare coverage. The man had just finished denouncing the insurance companies at a health care forum at a senior center when he fell ill. Dr. Anthony Alessi, a panelist at the forum, tried to resuscitate the man, but the man died at William W. Backus Hospital a short time later.

headline.main: Man Dies After Clash With Health Insurers

docs.abstract: Fredrick Kral, 72, suffers fatal heart attack as he and hundreds of other Connecticut seniors angrily confront insurance companies over cancellation of supplemental Medicare policies; forum was held in Norwich by Sen Christopher Dodd and Repr Sam Gejedenson

docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Democratic voters will choose a candidate to face Gov. George E. Pataki from among four contenders: Charles J. Hynes, James L. Larocca, Betsy McCaughey Ross and Peter F. Vallone. All four favor abortion rights, more money for early childhood education and day care, and drug treatment as an alternative to prison. They all also agree that the state should reduce its debt, ban anti-gay discrimination and help guarantee health insurance for the working poor.

headline.main: The Democratic Candidates for Governor at a Glance

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans unveiled the details of their proposed tax cuts today, laying out a package that they hope will overcome Democratic opposition by appealing to many married couples as well as to politically potent interest groups like farmers and small-business owners. The cuts would be worth about $80 billion over five years, far less than what some conservatives had been pressing for earlier this year but enough that paying for them would require dipping into projected Federal budget surpluses.

headline.main: G.O.P. Details Tax-Cut Plan With Benefits For 3 Groups

docs.abstract: Republicans unveil details of proposed tax cuts worth $80 billion over five years; call for reducing so-called marriage penalty, providing an exclusion for interest and dividend income of $200 for individuals and $400 for couples filing jointly and allowing the self-employed, including such powerful constituencies as farmers and small-business owners, to deduct a greater portion of their health-insurance premiums than they can under current law, which will not bring deduction to 100 percent until 2007; they would also accelerate a reduction in inheritance taxes; Pres Clinton, in weekly radio address, reiterates his view that budget surplus should be set aside until Social Security is saved (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A live two-way video link will allow passengers who are injured or become sick while traveling on the 109,000-ton Grand Princess, the world's newest and largest cruise ship, to get a second opinion. Cruise ships generally have medical offices and physicians on board who can consult with other physicians using radios. But the new system, known as Sea Med, allows on-board doctors to send video, X-ray images and other information for live consultations with emergency room physicians at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.

headline.main: Shipboard Video Link For Medical Matters

docs.abstract: Grand Princess, world's newest and largest ship, will have video link with Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, for consultations about passengers who have medical emergencies while on cruises (S)
